{{update|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox political party |country = Bulgaria |colorcode = #F66E22 |name = Order, Law and Justice |native_name = Ред, законност и справедливост |logo = 716 rzs logo.gif |logo_size = 250px |leader = [[Yane Yanev]] |foundation = 2005 |dissolved = 2009 |headquarters = [[Sofia]] |ideology = [[Conservatism]]{{Citation |first=Frederick B. |last=Chary |title=The History of Bulgaria |publisher=Greenwood |year=2011 |page=xxvi, 173}}{{cite web |url=http://www.pri-center.com/documents/Regional_Risk_Watch_090824.pdf |title=Regional Risk Watch: Central Eastern Europe |author= |date=24 August 2009 |publisher=Political Risk Insurance Center |accessdate=8 July 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.freedomhouse.eu/images/nit2010/NIT-2010-Bulgaria-proof-II.pdf |title=Bulgaria |author= |year=2010 |work=Nations in Transit 2010 |publisher=Freedom House |accessdate=8 July 2010}}
[[Populism]]{{cite news |title=Factbox: Main political parties in Bulgaria |first=Tsvetelia |last=Ilieva |author2=Ivanova, Irina |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=5 July 2009 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5640HP20090705 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.euractiv.com/en/enlargement/parliament-worried-bulgaria-tv-ban-plan/article-188451 |title=Parliament worried about Bulgaria TV ban plan |author= |date=18 December 2009 |publisher=EurActiv |accessdate=8 July 2010}} |position = [[Centre-right]]{{cite news |title=Order, Law and Justice party loses one more MP |first=Petar |last=Kostadinov |newspaper=[[The Sofia Echo]] |date=11 March 2010 |url=http://sofiaecho.com/2010/03/11/871432_order-law-and-justice-party-loses-one-more-mp }} to [[Right-wing (politics)|Right-wing]]{{Citation |url=http://www.sofiaecho.com/2010/01/14/842430_opposition-party-wants-11-cabinet-ministers-axed-over-alleged-conflict-of-interests |title=Opposition party wants 11 Cabinet ministers axed over alleged conflict of interests |newspaper=The Sofia Echo |date=14 Jan 2010 |accessdate=5 July 2011}}{{Citation |url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=96930 |title="Ataka" Nationalists Compile List of Most Corrupt Bulgarian Politicians |publisher=[[Novinite.com (Sofia News Agency)]] |date=12 Sep 2008 |accessdate=5 July 2011}} |international = ''None'' |european = ''None'' |colours = [[Blue]] and [[Orange (colour)|orange]] |website = [http://www.rzs.bg/ http://www.rzs.bg/] |seats1_title = [[National Assembly of Bulgaria|National Assembly]]: |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|240|hex=#F66E22}} |seats2_title = [[European Parliament]]: |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|17|hex=#F66E22}} }} '''Order, Law and Justice''' ({{lang-bg|Ред, законност и справедливост}}, ''Red, zakonnost i spravedlivost''), abbreviated to '''RZS''', was a [[conservative]] [[political party]] in [[Bulgaria]]. Its main focus is on fighting crime and corruption. It won the minimum ten seats in the [[National Assembly of Bulgaria|National Assembly]] at the [[Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2009|2009 election]], making it the smallest of the six parties in the legislature.{{cite news |title=Order, Law and Justice parliamentary group officially disbanded |first=Petar |last=Kostadinov |newspaper=[[Sofia Echo]] |date=9 December 2009 |url=http://sofiaecho.com/2009/12/09/827871_order-law-and-justice-parliamentary-group-officially-disbanded }} Later some of the deputies left the parliamentary group and it broke the minimum of ten, which inevitably made all parliamentary representatives of the party independent deputies. It is led by [[Yane Yanev]], who has frequently revealed classified documents backing up his claims of corruption.{{cite news |title=Borisov's turn |first= |last= |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |date=9 July 2009 |url= }} The party is close to the British [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]. The logo of Order, Law and Justice is a blue and orange checkerboard pattern. ==History== The party was founded by renaming and reforming the [[National Association - Bulgarian Agrarian People's Union]] (NS-BZNS), which had been part of the [[United Democratic Forces]], decided on the fourth congress of the NS-BZNS in the end of 2005. Its main goal is fighting corruption. In the [[European Parliament election, 2007 (Bulgaria)|2007 European election]], RZS won only 0.5% of the vote. By the time of the [[European Parliament election, 2009 (Bulgaria)|2009 election]], this had increased to 4.7%, with RZS claiming that only [[electoral fraud]] had prevented it from receiving 10%, which would have given it two seats.{{cite news |title=Bulgaria Opposition RZS Suspicious of Vote Manipulation |first= |last= |newspaper=[[Sofia News Agency]] |date=8 June 2009 |url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=104488 }} A month later, RZS took part in [[Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2009|elections to]] the [[National Assembly of Bulgaria|National Assembly]]. Its parliamentary ticket was headed by [[Atanas Semov]], a law professor at the [[University of Sofia]]. Its platform called for the formation of a stable center-right coalition that would exclude the [[Bulgarian Socialist Party]], a proactive campaign against political corruption, compulsory education until age 16, greater efforts to fight illiteracy, and the rejection of [[ethnic nationalism]] in politics. The election saw RZS win 4.13% of the vote: just clearing the 4% [[election threshold|threshold]] and entitling it to ten seats. The party supported the new centre-right government under [[Boyko Borisov]], but refused to sign an official declaration of support, after pressure from the [[European Conservatives and Reformists]] over the involvement of [[Attack (political party)|Attack]].{{cite news |title=Bulgaria Conservative Party Refuses to Sign GERB Memorandum |first= |last= |newspaper=[[Sofia News Agency]] |date=17 July 2009 |url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=105871&FORM=ZZNR6 }} One of RZS's MPs, [[Mario Tagarinski]], left the party on 9 December 2009, pushing the party below the minimum of ten MPs required to form an official [[parliamentary group]]. Another MP, [[Dimitar Choukarski]], left on 11 March 2010, reducing it further to eight MPs. The party nominated [[Atanas Semov]] for president during the [[Bulgarian presidential election, 2011|2011]] presidential election. He finished seventh with only 1.84% of the popular vote. In the [[Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2013|2013]] parliamentary election the party won only 1.67% of the popular vote and failed to win a seat. ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.rzs.bg/ Official website] {{Bulgarian political parties}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Order Law And Justice}} [[Category:Conservative parties in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Anti-corruption parties]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2005]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Alliance of Conservatives and Reformists in Europe member parties]] [[Category:European Conservatives and Reformists member parties]]

revision.text:
{{wikt|oligarch}} '''Russian oligarchs''' (see the related term "[[New Russians]]") are [[business oligarch]]s of the [[former Soviet republics]] who rapidly accumulated wealth during the era of [[privatization in Russia|Russian privatization]] in the aftermath of the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] in the 1990s. The [[Failed state| failing]] [[USSR| Soviet]] state left the ownership of state assets contested, which allowed for [[Blat (favors)| informal deals]] with former USSR officials (mostly in [[Russia]] and [[Ukraine]]) as a means to acquire state property. Historian [[Edward L. Keenan]] has drawn a comparison between the current Russian phenomenon of oligarchs and the system of powerful [[Boyar#Boyars in Muscovy |boyars]] which emerged in late-Medieval [[Muscovy]].<ref name="Russia's Oligarchy, Alive and Well">[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/31/opinion/russias-oligarchy-alive-and-well.html?_r=0 "Russia's Oligarchy, Alive and Well"], by Andrew S. Weiss, ''New York Times'', December 30, 2013. {{webarchive|url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170204210417/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/31/opinion/russias-oligarchy-alive-and-well.html?_r=0 |date= February 4, 2017 }}</ref>
The first modern Russian [[oligarchy| oligarchs]] emerged as [[business sector | business-sector]] [[entrepreneur]]s under [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] ([[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union| General Secretary]] 1985–1991) during his period of [[Market economy |market]] liberalization.<ref>[[Walter Scheidel|Scheidel, Walter]] (2017). ''The Great Leveler: Violence and the History of Inequality from the Stone Age to the Twenty-First Century''. Princeton University Press. pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=NgZpDQAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA51#v=onepage&q&f=false 51] & [https://books.google.com/books?id=NgZpDQAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA222#v=onepage&q&f=false 222-223]</ref>{{qn|date=October 2018}} The term [[oligarchy| "oligarch"]] derives from the Ancient Greek word ὀλιγάρχης (oligárkhēs), meaning literally "one of few rulers".
==Yeltsin era== By the end of the Soviet era in 1991 and during [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]], many Russian businessmen imported or smuggled goods such as [[personal computer]]s and [[jeans]] into the country and sold them, often on the [[black market]], for a hefty profit. [[File:Анатолий Чубайс.jpg|thumb|170px|[[Anatoly Chubais]], the man most credited with the Yeltsin-era privatization that led to the growth of the oligarchs<ref name=ProfileAnatoly>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4357755.stm Profile: Anatoly Chubais,” BBC News, March 17,2005]</ref>]]
During the 1990s, once [[Boris Yeltsin]] became [[President of Russia]] in 1991, the oligarchs emerged as well-connected entrepreneurs who started from nearly nothing and became rich through participation in the [[market (economics)|market]] via connections to the corrupt, but elected, [[government of Russia]] during the state's transition to a [[market-based economy]]. The so-called [[voucher privatization|voucher-privatization]] program enabled a handful of young men to become billionaires, specifically by [[arbitrage|arbitraging]] the vast difference between old domestic prices for Russian commodities (e.g. [[Natural gas|gas]], oil) and the prices prevailing on the world market. Because they stashed billions of dollars in private [[Swiss bank accounts]] rather than investing in the [[Russian economy]], they were dubbed "[[kleptocrat]]s".<ref name=Granville>Johanna Granville, [https://www.academia.edu/5597850/The_Russian_Kleptocracy_and_Rise_of_Organized_Crime "The Russian Kleptocracy and Rise of Organized Crime."] ''Demokratizatsiya'' (summer 2003), pp. 448-457.</ref> These oligarchs became extremely unpopular with the Russian public, and are commonly thought of as the cause of much of the turmoil that plagued the country following the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.<ref>Holmstrom, Nancy; Richard Smith (February 2000). [http://monthlyreview.org/2000/02/01/the-necessity-of-gangster-capitalism "The Necessity of Gangster Capitalism: Primitive Accumulation in Russia and China"]. ''Monthly Review''. Monthly Review Foundation. '''51''' (09).</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' described the oligarchs as "about as popular with your average Russian as a man idly burning bundles of £50s outside an orphanage".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6708103.stm Profile: Boris Berezovsky] [[BBC]] Retrieved on April 28, 2008</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/russia/article/0,,1655229,00.html What a carve-up!] ''[[The Guardian]]'' Retrieved on April 28, 2008</ref>
Post-Soviet business oligarchs include relatives or close associates of government officials, even government officials themselves, as well as [[crime in Russia|criminal bosses]] often connected to the Russian government<ref>https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/organized-crime-russia</ref> who achieved vast wealth by acquiring state assets very cheaply (or for free) during the [[privatization in Russia|privatization process]] controlled by the Yeltsin government of 1991–1999.<ref>[[Chrystia Freeland|Freeland, Chrystia]] (2000). ''Sale of the Century: Russia's Wild Ride from Communism to Capitalism''. New York: Crown Business.</ref> Specific accusations of [[Corporate crime|corruption]] are often leveled at [[Anatoly Chubais]] and [[Yegor Gaidar]], two of the "Young Reformers" chiefly responsible for [[Russian privatization]] in the early 1990s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cs.ccsu.edu/~gusev/russian/gybio.html|title=Grigory Yavlinsky|website=www.cs.ccsu.edu|access-date=2017-07-30}}</ref><ref>[http://www.freepatentsonline.com/article/SAM-Advanced-Management-Journal/98831087.html Privatization in Russia: its past, present, and future] SAM Advanced Management Journal, 1 January 2003. Retrieved 31 July 2017</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8416497.stm Yegor Gaidar: The price to pay] [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 31 July 2017</ref> According to [[David Satter]], author of ''Darkness at Dawn'', "what drove the process was not the determination to create a system based on [[universal value]]s but rather the will to introduce a system of private ownership, which, in the absence of law, opened the way for the criminal pursuit of money and power".<ref>Satter, David. ''Darkness at Dawn: The Rise of the Russian Criminal State''. Yale University Press, 2008.</ref> In some cases, outright criminal groups – in order to avoid attention – assign front-men to serve as executives and/or "legal" owners of the companies they control.
Although the majority of oligarchs were not formally connected with the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]], there are allegations that they were promoted (at least initially) by the communist [[apparatchik]]s, with strong connections to Soviet power structures and access to the monetary funds of the Communist Party.<ref>Virtual Politics – Faking Democracy in the Post-Soviet World, [[Andrew Wilson (historian)|Andrew Wilson]], [[Yale University Press]], 2005</ref><ref>Braguinsky, Serguey, and Roger Myerson. "A macroeconomic model of Russian transition." ''Economics of Transition'' 15.1 (2007): 77–107.</ref> Official Russian media usually depict oligarchs as the enemies of "communist forces". The latter is a [[stereotype]] that describes political power that wants to restore Soviet-style communism in Russia.
During Yeltsin's presidency (1991–1999) oligarchs became increasingly influential in Russian politics; they played a significant role in financing the [[Russian presidential election, 1996|re-election of Yeltsin in 1996]]. With [[insider information]] about financial decisions of the government, oligarchs could easily increase their wealth even further. The [[1998 Russian financial crisis]] hit some of the oligarchs hard, however, and those whose holdings were still based mainly on banking lost much of their fortunes.
The most influential and exposed oligarchs from the Yeltsin era include [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]], [[Mikhail Fridman]], [[Vladimir Gusinsky]], [[Mikhail Khodorkovsky]], [[Vladimir Potanin]], [[Alexander Smolensky]], [[Pyotr Aven]], [[Vladimir Vinogradov]] and [[Vitaly Malkin]].<ref>http://www.sjsu.edu/faculty/watkins/oligarchs.htm</ref><ref>[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:LCYNMjG-y8oJ:www.themoscowtimes.com/sitemap/free/1996/11/article/british-paper-names-banking-clique/316590.html+&cd=10&hl=en&ct=clnk British Paper Names Banking Clique] at ''[[The Moscow Times]]'', November 5, 1996 (archived)</ref><ref>Dmitry Butrin. "[http://kommersant.ru/doc/312965 The Results of 10 Years of Capitalism]". ''[[Kommersant]]'', March 5, 2002 (in Russian)</ref> They formed what became known as [[Semibankirschina]] (or seven bankers), a small group of business moguls with a great influence on Boris Yeltsin and his political environment. Together they controlled from 50% to 70% of all Russian finances between 1996 and 2000.
Fridman, Potanin, Aven and Malkin are the only ones on the list to have retained their influence in the Putin era, which began in 1999. Khodorkovsky, Berezovsky and Gusinsky "have been purged by the Kremlin", according to ''[[The Guardian]]'' in 2008.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/feb/19/russia Billionaires boom as Putin puts oligarchs at N2 in global rich list The Guardian, 19 Feb 2008]</ref>
==Putin era== {{further|Russia under Vladimir Putin}} The most famous oligarchs of the Putin era include [[Roman Abramovich]], [[Alexander Abramov]], [[Oleg Deripaska]], [[Mikhail Prokhorov]], [[Alisher Usmanov]], [[German Khan]], [[Viktor Vekselberg]], [[Leonid Mikhelson]], [[Vagit Alekperov]], [[Mikhail Fridman]], [[Vladimir Potanin]], [[Pyotr Aven]], and [[Vitaly Malkin]].
Between 2000 and 2004, Putin apparently engaged in a power-struggle with some oligarchs, reaching a "grand bargain" with them. This bargain allowed the oligarchs to maintain their powers, in exchange for their explicit support of – and alignment with – Putin's government.<ref>''Putin: Russia's Choice''. Richard Sakwa, (Routledge, 2008) pp 143-150</ref><ref>Playing Russian Roulette: Putin in search of good governance, by Andre Mommen, in ''Good Governance in the Era of Global is Neoliberalism: Conflict and Depolitisation in Latin America, Eastern Europe, Asia, and Africa'', by Jolle Demmers, Alex E. Fernández Jilberto, Barbara Hogenboom (Routledge, 2004)</ref> Many more [[business people]] have become oligarchs during Putin's time in power, and often due to personal relations with Putin, such as the rector of the institute where Putin obtained a degree in 1996, [[Vladimir Litvinenko]],<ref name="Bureau">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebureauinvestigates.com/2012/03/02/the-fabulous-riches-of-putins-inner-circle/ |title=The fabulous riches of Putin's inner circle |publisher=The Bureau Investigates |accessdate=June 7, 2012}}</ref> and Putin's childhood friend and [[judo]]-teacher [[Arkady Rotenberg]].<ref>[http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/russian-oligarchs-2013-4/ Oligarchology] by Alex Yablon, ''New York Magazine'', Mar 31, 2013</ref> However, other analysts argue that the oligarchic structure has remained intact under Putin, with Putin devoting much of his time to mediating power-disputes between rival oligarchs.<ref name="Russia's Oligarchy, Alive and Well" /> Some had been imprisoned, such as [[Mikhael Mirilashvili]].
During Putin's presidency, a number of oligarchs came under fire for various illegal activities, particularly [[tax evasion]] in the businesses they acquired. However, it is widely speculated and believed that the charges were also politically motivated per these tycoons falling out of favor with the Kremlin.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/european_court_rules_khodorkovskys_rights_violated/24210627.html European Court Rules That Khodorkovsky's Rights Were Violated], Radio Free Europe, 31 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.euronews.com/2013/12/22/former-russian-tycoon-mikhail-khodorkovsky-first-news-conference-released-prison/ "Khodorkovsky speaks out on plight of Russia's political prisoners"]. Euronews. Retrieved 30 December 2013.</ref> [[Vladimir Gusinsky]] of MediaMost and [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]] both avoided legal proceedings by leaving Russia, and the most prominent, [[Mikhail Khodorkovsky]] of [[Yukos]] [[Petroleum|oil]], was arrested in October 2003 and sentenced to 9 years. This was subsequently extended to 14 years, and after Putin pardoned him, he was released on 20 December 2013.<ref name="YukosCase">{{cite news|title=Hague court awards $50 bn compensation to Yukos shareholders|url=http://www.russiaherald.com/index.php/sid/224207121/scat/723971d98160d438/ht/Hague-court-awards-50-bn-compensation-to-Yukos-shareholders|accessdate=29 July 2014 |work=Russia Herald}}</ref> The term 'oligarch' has also been applied to technology investors such as [[Yuri Milner]], although without involvement in Russian politics.<ref name=wired-mag>[https://www.wired.com/magazine/2011/10/mf_milner/all/ Wired Magazine: "How Russian Tycoon Yuri Milner Bought His Way Into Silicon Valley" by Michael Wolff] October 21, 2011</ref>
Defenders of the out-of-favor oligarchs, often associated with Chubais's party—the [[Union of Right Forces]], argue that the companies they acquired were not highly valued at the time because they still ran on [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] principles, with non-existent [[stock control|stock-control]], huge payrolls, no financial reporting and scant regard for profit. They turned the businesses around and made them profitable for shareholders. They obtain little sympathy from the Russian public due to resentment over the economic disparity they represent.
An economic study distinguishes 21 oligarchic groups as of 2003.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= Guriev |first1= Sergei |last2= Rachinsky |first2= Andrei |title= The role of oligarchs in Russian capitalism |journal= Journal of Economic Perspectives |date=2005|pages=131-150|doi= 10.1257/0895330053147994|url= https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/0895330053147994 |volume=19|issue=1}}</ref>
In 2004, ''[[Forbes]]'' listed 36 billionaires of Russian citizenship, with a note: "this list includes businessmen of Russian citizenship who acquired the major share of their wealth privately, while not holding a governmental position". In 2005, the number of billionaires dropped to 30, mostly because of the [[Yukos]] case, with Khodorkovsky dropping from #1 (US$15.2 billion) to #21 (US$2.0 billion).
A 2013 report by Credit Suisse found that 35% of the wealth of Russia was owned by the wealthiest 110 individuals.<ref>{{cite web |title=The world's wealthy: where on earth are the richest 1%? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2013/oct/09/worlds-wealthy-where-russia-rich-list |website=The Guardian |accessdate=19 September 2018}}</ref>
Billionaire, philanthropist, art patron and former KGB agent [[Alexander Lebedev]] has criticized the oligarchs, saying "I think material wealth for them is a highly emotional and spiritual thing. They spend a lot of money on their own personal consumption." Lebedev has also described them as "a bunch of uncultured ignoramuses", saying "They don't read books. They don't have time. They don't go to [art] exhibitions. They think the only way to impress anyone is to buy a yacht." He also notes that the oligarchs have no interest in social injustice.<ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/oct/25/russian-oligarchs-oleg-deripaska |work=The Guardian |location=London |title=Twilight of the oligarchs |first=Luke |last=Harding |date=October 25, 2008 |accessdate=April 1, 2010}}</ref>
In 2018, the [[USA Treasury]] published a [[Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act#List of Russian tycoons named in the CAATSA unclassified report|"list of oligarchs" per Pub.L. 115–44]].
===Oligarchs in London=== A significant number of Russian oligarchs have bought homes in upmarket sections of [[London]]<ref>Michael Weiss, ''IN PLAIN SIGHT: The Kremlin's London Lobby'', World Affairs, Vol. 175, No. 6 (MARCH / APRIL 2013), pp. 84-91.</ref> in the [[United Kingdom]], which has been dubbed "Moscow on Thames."<ref>According to British journalist Nick Watt, reporting for ABC's ''[[Nightline (US news program)|Nightline]]''. (broadcast of June 1, 2007)</ref> Some, such as [[Eugene Shvidler]], [[Alexander Knaster]], [[Konstantin Kagalovsky]] and Abram Reznikov, are [[expatriate]]s, having taken permanent residency in London. This community has led to journalists calling the city "Londongrad". Most own homes in both countries as well as property and have acquired controlling interests in major European companies. They commute on a regular basis between the [[European Union|EU]] and Russia; in many cases their families reside in London, with their children attending school there. In 2007 Abram Reznikov bought one of Spain's mega recycling companies, Alamak Espana Trade SL, while [[Roman Abramovich]] bought the English football club, [[Chelsea F.C.]], in 2003, spending record amounts on players' salaries.<ref>"Over there: American and other foreign owners are revolutionizing British football", ''[[Boston Globe]],'' May 25, 2007</ref>
The billionaire Moscow oligarch [[Mikhail Fridman]], Russia's second richest man as of 2016, is currently restoring [[Athlone House]] in London as a primary residence,<ref>[http://www.hamhigh.co.uk/news/new_athlone_house_owner_i_want_to_restore_it_to_its_former_glory_1_4598330 New Athlone House owner: ‘I want to restore it to its former glory’] 11:21 30 June 2016 Anna Behrmann, Ham and High</ref> to be worth an estimated £130 million when restored.<ref>[http://money.aol.co.uk/2016/09/15/billionaires-plans-for-derelict-mansion-approved Billionaire's plans for £65 million derelict mansion approved] By Emma Woollacott Sep 15, 2016</ref>
===2008 global recession and credit crisis=== According to the financial news-agency [[Bloomberg L.P.]], Russia's wealthiest 25 individuals have collectively lost US $230 billion (£146 billion) since July 2008.<ref>Chorafas, D. ''Capitalism without capital''. Springer, 2009.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/rich-russians-losing-lots-of-money-ruble-2014-12|title=Russia's Richest Have Lost $62 Billion This Year|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-12-17/russian-rich-lose-10-billion-in-two-days-as-ruble-drops|title=Russian Rich Lose $10 Billion in Two Days as Ruble Drops|publisher=Bloomberg|access-date=2017-07-30}}</ref> The fall in the oligarchs' wealth relates closely to the meltdown in Russia's stock market, as by 2008 the [[RTS Index]] had lost 71% of its value due to the [[capital flight]] after the [[Russo-Georgian War]] of August 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/05/business/worldbusiness/05oligarchs.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss |work=The New York Times |title=Russia's Oligarchs May Face a Georgian Chill |first=Landon |last=Thomas Jr. |date=September 5, 2008 |accessdate=April 1, 2010}}</ref>
Billionaires in Russia and Ukraine have been particularly hard-hit by lenders seeking repayment on [[balloon loan]]s in order to shore up their own balance sheets. Many oligarchs took out generous loans from Russian banks, bought shares, and then took out more loans from western banks against the value of these shares.<ref name="guardian.co.uk" /><ref name="forbes.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/business/2008/10/23/billionaires-margin-calls-biz-billies-cx_af_1023billiemargin.html |title=Margin Calls Ignite Billionaire Fire Sale|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026022503/http://www.forbes.com/business/2008/10/23/billionaires-margin-calls-biz-billies-cx_af_1023billiemargin.html|archivedate=2008-10-26}}</ref> One of the first to get hit by the global downturn was [[Oleg Deripaska]], Russia's richest man at the time, who had a net worth of US$28 billion in March 2008. As Deripaska borrowed money from western banks using shares in his companies as collateral, the collapse in share price forced him to sell holdings to satisfy the [[margin call]]s.<ref name="guardian.co.uk" /><ref name="forbes.com" />
==See also== * [[Oligarchy]] * [[Tycoon]] * [[Privatization in Russia]] * [[Semibankirschina]] * [[Ukrainian oligarchs]] * [[Robber baron (industrialist)]] * [[Russian mafia]] * [[Political groups under Vladimir Putin's presidency]] * [[Media mogul]]

{{for|"salami slicing" in publishing|Salami publication}} {{for|the literal means of preparing salami sausage|Salami}} '''Salami slicing''' refers to a series of many small actions, often performed by clandestine means, that as an accumulated whole produces a much larger action or result that would be difficult or unlawful to perform all at once. The term is typically used [[pejoratively]]. Although salami slicing is often used to carry out illegal activities, it is only a strategy for gaining an advantage over time by accumulating it in small increments, so it can be used in legal ways as well. An example of [[salami]] slicing, also known as '''penny shaving''', is the [[fraud]]ulent practice of stealing money repeatedly in extremely small quantities, usually by taking advantage of [[rounding]] to the nearest cent (or other monetary unit) in financial transactions. It would be done by always rounding down, and putting the fractions of a cent into another account. The idea is to make the change small enough that any single transaction will go undetected.{{cite web|url=http://all.net/CID/Attack/papers/Salami2.html|title=Salami Attacks}} In [[information security]], a '''salami attack''' is a series of minor attacks that together results in a larger attack. Computers are ideally suited to automating this type of attack. In politics, the term [[salami tactics]] has been used since the 1940s to refer to a [[Divide and rule|divide and conquer]] process of threats and alliances used to overcome opposition. In academia, salami slicing refers to the practice of creating several short publications out of material that could have, perhaps more validly, been published as a single article in a journal or review. (See also [[least publishable unit]]). ==Salami slicing attacks== In January 1993, four executives of a rental-car franchise in Florida were charged with defrauding at least 47,000 customers using a salami technique.[http://www.mekabay.com/nwss/116p--salami_fraud.pdf Salami fraud] By M. E. Kabay Network World Security Newsletter, 07/24/02 In Los Angeles, in October 1998, district attorneys charged four men with fraud for allegedly installing computer chips in gasoline pumps that cheated consumers by overstating the amounts pumped. In 2008, a man was arrested for fraudulently creating 58,000 accounts which he used to collect money through verification deposits from online brokerage firms a few cents at a time.{{cite news|url=http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/201252/hacker-takes-50000-a-few-cents-at-a-time.html|title=Hacker takes $50,000 a few cents at a time|date=2008-05-28|publisher=PC Pro}} == In politics == On 6 September 2018 British [[Member of Parliament (UK)|MP]] [[Tom Tugendhat]], in a [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] speech, accused the Russian Government of salami slicing tactics:{{Cite web|url=https://hansard.parliament.uk/Commons/2018-09-06/debates/7073CC9A-53E4-4157-88F9-495945616E03/GlobalBritainAndTheInternationalRules-BasedOrder|title=Hansard 6 September 2018 - Global Britain and the International Rules-based Order|last=|first=|date=6 September 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=6 September 2018}} {{Quote|text=We have seen the physical reality of that in the energy markets, with the Russian Government deliberately salami-slicing those markets in order to salami-slice alliances.|sign=|source=}} == In fiction == ===Film=== Salami slicing has played a key role in the plots of several films, including ''[[Superman III]]'', ''[[Hackers (film)|Hackers]]'', and ''[[Office Space#Plot|Office Space]]''. In the latter title, the characters reference ''Superman III'' as inspiration.{{cite web | title = The Salami Technique |url = http://www.snopes.com/business/bank/salami.asp}} ===Television=== In a 1972 episode of the TV series ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'', [[Radar O'Reilly|Radar]] attempts to ship an entire [[Jeep]] home from Korea one piece at a time. Hawkeye commented that his mailman "would have a retroactive hernia" if he found out.{{cite web |work=M*A*S*H | title = Season 1 Ep 12 | url = http://www.tv.com/M%2AA%2AS%2AH/Dear+Dad/episode/43211/summary.html}} The 1987 TV movie Perry Mason: The Case of the Murdered Madam features a murder trial involving the transfer of fractional cents by bank employees. ===Music=== [[Johnny Cash]]'s "[[One Piece at a Time]]" has a similar plot to the ''M*A*S*H'' episode, but with a Cadillac having parts from model years 1949 through 1973.{{cite web | title = One Step at a Time | url = http://www.dieseltechmag.com/2014/07/one-step-at-a-time}} ==See also== * [[Structuring]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cs.bgsu.edu/maner/ethicomp95/keynote3-THE.html#Heading15 How computers enable salami slicing to occur] *[http://www.mekabay.com/nwss/116p--salami_fraud.pdf A ''Network World'' article] discussing salami fraud, with several examples [[Category:Fraud]] [[Category:Data security]]

The '''Scottish Aquaculture Innovation Centre''' (SAIC) was set up in 2014, funded by the [[Scottish Funding Council]], [[Scottish Enterprise]], and [[Highlands and Islands Enterprise]], with funding matched by the industry. It is hosted by the [[University of Stirling]].
The role of SAIC is to transform the relationship between the aquaculture industry and research communities in Scotland. By developing connections and collaboration between them, it aims to promote innovative solutions to industry-defined issues and problems.
== Aquaculture and Scotland == [[Aquaculture]] is a “pillar of rural industry in Scotland”, according to the Scottish Government, contributing as much as £1.4 billion turnover and 8,000 jobs to Scotland.<ref>Marine Scotland (April 2014). “An Assessment of the Benefits to Scotland of Aquaculture”. http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Resource/0045/00450799.pdf. Retrieved 11 November 2014.</ref> Its industry and academic researchers also contribute to Scotland’s reputation abroad. The main activities within the sector are the farming / culturing of fish, molluscs, crustaceans and seaweed, much of them in the [[seas west of Scotland]] and north of Scotland.
Salmon dominates the sector, and Scotland is the largest producer in the EU and the third largest globally.<ref>Scottish Salmon Producers Organisation, Annual Report 2013. http://scottishsalmon.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/FINAL-Annual-Report-aug-14.pdf Retrieved 11 November 2014.</ref> Current annual production of salmon in Scotland is about 160,000 tonnes, generating global retail sales of more than £1 billion. Fresh salmon is exported to over 50 countries, with the US the main export market for fresh whole salmon in 2013, followed by France.<ref>Scottish Salmon Producers Organisation, Annual Report 2013. http://scottishsalmon.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/FINAL-Annual-Report-aug-14.pdf Retrieved 11 November 2014.</ref>
== Aims of SAIC == By bringing together the industry and research communities, SAIC aims to foster further economic growth in the industry, introduce more sustainable practices, and prepare the industry for the future. To target its work most effectively, it has identified four Priority Innovation Actions for its first year of operations: • Improved sea lice control in Scottish aquaculture • Alternative sustainable feeds for finfish • Rapid detection methods for viral pathogens and diseases • Development of secure health-certified Scottish mollusc spat production systems.<ref>Scottish Aquaculture Innovation Centre, Executive Summary. {{cite web |url=http://scottishaquaculture.com/scottish-aquaculture-news-events |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141114155808/http://scottishaquaculture.com/scottish-aquaculture-news-events |archivedate=2014-11-14 |df= }} Retrieved 11 November 2014.</ref>
All these areas have been identified by the industry, its customers and communities as the most pressing areas requiring innovation and collaboration.
Scotland and its rural communities could benefit greatly from action in these areas. It is estimated that each additional 10,000 tonnes of salmon creates an additional £96 million for the Scottish economy, of which over £43 million is at the farm gate.<ref>Science Scotland, Issue 16, Special Issue: Innovation Centres (Autumn 2014). http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/publications/sciencescotland/ScienceScotland16.pdf Retrieved 11 November 2014.</ref>
== History and structure of SAIC == The Scottish Aquaculture Innovation Centre was launched by the Scottish Government’s Minister for Environment and Climate Change, Paul Wheelhouse, at the Royal Highland Show at Ingliston in 2014. Its Chair is Jack Perry, a former CEO of Scottish Enterprise, and its CEO is Heather Jones.
One of its first actions was to secure £1.7 million funding for state-of-the-art equipment to help address key issues in the industry. The equipment will be installed at higher education institutions across Scotland, including the University of St Andrews, University of the Highlands and Islands, University of Aberdeen and University of Stirling.<ref>SAIC, “£1.7 million capital investment for Scottish Aquaculture” (6 November 2014). {{cite web |url=http://scottishaquaculture.com/scottish-aquaculture-news-events |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141114155808/http://scottishaquaculture.com/scottish-aquaculture-news-events |archivedate=2014-11-14 |df= }} Retrieved 11 November 2014.</ref>
SAIC is one of eight Innovation Centres funded by the Scottish Funding Council, which is investing up to £110 million in core funding over five years. In addition to the Scottish Aquaculture Innovation Centre, they include: the Innovation Centre for Sensors and Imaging Systems (CENSIS); Digital Health Institute (DHI); Oil & Gas Innovation Centre (OGIC); and Stratified Medicine Scotland Innovation Centre (SMS-IC).<ref>Science Scotland, Issue 16, Special Issue: Innovation Centres (Autumn 2014). http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/publications/sciencescotland/ScienceScotland16.pdf Retrieved 11 November 2014.</ref>
Commenting on the launch of the Centres and their work, the Scottish Government Education Secretary Mike Russell stated: “The innovation centre collaborations ... will help develop the skills that Scottish business needs to success in the global marketplace in a range of sectors.
“By using Scotland’s exceptional research base, we are able to respond nimbly to opportunities for potential growth.”<ref>“£14 million boost for Scotland’s innovation centres”. The Scotsman. 20 August 2014.</ref>

{{About|secretaries as leaders in organizations|the common meaning of secretary as an office support worker, which can also be a title|secretary}} '''Secretary''' is a title often used in organizations to indicate a person having a certain amount of [[authority]], [[Power (social and political)|power]], or importance in the organization. Secretaries announce important events and communicate to the organization. The term is derived from the Latin word {{lang|la|secernere}}, "to distinguish" or "to set apart", the passive participle ({{lang|la|secretum}}) meaning "having been set apart", with the eventual connotation of something private or confidential, as with the English word ''secret.'' A {{lang|la|secretarius}} was a person, therefore, overseeing business confidentially, usually for a powerful individual (a king, pope, etc.).
The official title of the leader of most [[communist party|communist]] and [[socialist party|socialist]] political parties is the "'''General Secretary of the Central Committee'''" or "'''First Secretary of the Central Committee'''". When a communist party is in power, the General Secretary is usually the country's ''[[de facto]]'' leader (though sometimes this leader also holds state-level positions to monopolize power, such as a [[President#Presidents_as_head_of_state|presidency]] or [[premier]]ship in order to constitute ''[[de jure]]'' leadership of the state), such as [[China]] and [[Cuba]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Xi's here to stay: China leader tipped to outstay term|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3730755/Xis-stay-China-leader-tipped-outstay-term.html|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=9 August 2016|quote="A lot of analysts now see it as a given" that Xi will seek to stay [[Communist Party of China|Party]] [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of China|General Secretary]], the [[China|country]]'s most powerful [[Paramount leader|post]], said Christopher K. Johnson, a former CIA analyst and now China specialist at the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies.}}</ref>
In England, the term ''secretarius'' was used "from the beginning of the thirteenth century in the varying meanings of a confidential clerk, an ambassador, or a member of the king's council".<ref name="Ruthven">J. Otway-Ruthven, ''The King's Secretary and the Signet Office in the XV Century'' (1939), p. 60.</ref> In the fourteenth century, the title became strongly associated with the keeper of the king's [[signet ring|signet]].<ref name="Ruthven"/> From the [[Renaissance]] to the late 19th century, men involved in the daily correspondence and the activities of the powerful assumed the title of secretary. With time, like many titles, the term was applied to more and varied functions, leading to compound titles to specify the authority associated with its use, like general secretary or [[financial secretary]].
In some countries, such as the United States, the term ''secretary'' is used to indicate the holder of a [[cabinet (government)|cabinet]]-level post. This usage derives in part from the desire of the founders of the United States to differentiate the country from the United Kingdom,{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}} which denoted such offices as [[minister (government)|ministers]]. There are a number of popular variations of the title used to indicate that the secretary in question has a high degree of authority, such as '''general secretary''' (or, following usage in the [[Norman language]], '''secretary-general'''), '''first secretary''', and '''executive secretary'''.
In a [[club (organization)|club]] or [[society]], the secretary is also considered to be, in most cases, the third person in charge of the organization, after the president/chairman and vice president/vice chairman.<ref name="Roberts">''Robert's Rules of Order Newly Revised'', 4th edition, Scott, Foresman and Company, Chicago, 1915, pp. 244–247.</ref> In smaller organizations, the secretary typically takes [[meeting minutes]], notifies members of meetings, contacts various persons in relation to the society, administers the day-to-day activities of the organization, and creates the order of business. The secretary of a [[non-governmental organization]] or [[international non-governmental organization]] can be vice president/vice chairman.<ref name="Roberts"/>
==General secretary==
General secretary occurs as the title of a [[Minister (government)|ministerial]] position of authority found in various organizations, such as [[trade union]]s, [[communism|communist]] and [[socialism|socialist]] parties, and [[international non-governmental organization]]s. Examples include:
*[[General Secretary of the Communist Party]] *[[General Secretary of the Communist Party of China]] *[[General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam]] *[[General Secretary of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party]] *[[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] *[[Jeronimo de Sousa|General Secretary of the Portuguese Communist Party]] *[[General Secretary of the Communist Party of Kampuchea]] *[[General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Mongolian People's Party]] *[[General Secretary of the Labour Party]] *[[General Secretary of the Trades Union Congress]] * Some church organizations, such as the [[National Council of Churches]] and the [[World Council of Churches]]

==First secretary==
First secretary is the title of the chief officer or leader in many organizations, and is also a modern [[diplomatic rank]]. Examples include: * Some consumer organizations, such as the [[National Consumers League]] * Some political parties, especially [[Communist party|Communist]] or [[Socialist Party|Socialist Parties]] * [[First Secretary of State]], a cabinet position in the United Kingdom * First Secretary for Wales, now [[First Minister of Wales]] * First Secretary of the Admiralty—see [[Secretary to the Admiralty]] <!-- Alphabetical by country --> * In Workers' Party and Communist Party organizations: ** First Secretary of the [[Communist Party of Armenia (Soviet Union)]] ** First Secretary of the [[Communist Party of China]]—see [[Party Committee Secretary|Party chief of the Communist Party of China]] *** First Secretary of the [[Communist Youth League of China]] ** [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Cuba]] ** First Secretary of the [[Communist Party of Czechoslovakia]] ** [[First Secretary of the French Socialist Party]] ** [[First Secretary of the Georgian Communist Party]] ** [[First Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea]] ** First Secretary of the Central Committee of the [[Communist Party of Lithuania]] ** [[Polish United Workers' Party#Party leaders|First Secretary of the Central Committee of Polish United Workers' Party]] ** First Secretary of the [[Communist Party of the Russian Federation]] ** First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union—see [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] *** [[Moscow City Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|First Secretary of the Moscow Communist Party]] ** [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Tajikistan]] ** First Secretary of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine (Soviet Union)]] ** [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam|First Secretary of the Workers' Party of Vietnam]] * Some [[trade union]]s, especially in the United Kingdom * The [[Ministry of Macedonia and Thrace|General Secretariat for Macedonia and Thrace]], a government agency for the Greek regions of Macedonia and Thrace
